with no bounds or limits—
its left and right cannot be fixed.

All things rely on it for birth
yet it does not claim them.
Though its achievements are complete and its functions fulfilled,
it does not name itself.

It is covered by all things yet does not rule them—
thus it may be called *small*;
All things return to it yet it does not rule them—
thus it may be called *great*.

Though all things depend on the Great Dao for birth,
and names and functions are established,
they do not know that these names belong to the Great Dao.

All things rely on the Great Dao,
yet do not depend on its ruler—
thus it is called *small*.

All things ultimately depend on the Great Dao as their ruler—
thus it is called *great*.

The Sage never claims to be *great*—
thus he can achieve true greatness.

The Sage embodies the Great Dao,
yet does not name himself—
thus he fulfills the name of true greatness.

**Thirty-Fifth Chapter**
To grasp the great image,
the Great Dao flows throughout the world.

It goes yet does not harm,
bringing peace and tranquility.

Delighting in the five tones is like stopping at a tavern for food and drink—
a traveler lingers briefly but does not stay long.

The Dao, when expressed in words,
is bland and tasteless;
seen, it is not fully visible;
heard, it is not fully audible;
used, it cannot be exhausted.

The Sage holds fast to the Great Dao,
goes forth to govern the world,
and many find peace and tranquility.

After peace and tranquility,
people grow heavy with joy, music, and feasting—
when joy reaches its peak, sorrow follows;
when rites become excessive, disorder arises.
Thus, the Dao is used to restrain them.

Joy and music are like a traveler stopping at a tavern—
he stays briefly but soon departs.
Better to uphold the bland, tasteless Dao,
for its use is inexhaustible.

*Exhaust* is akin to *complete*.

**Thirty-Sixth Chapter**」

chunks.original_text: 德经 述夫道者，万物之始也无形； 德者，万物之用也有象。 德生於道，道成於德，至德至道，一也。 得之者生，失之者死。 圣人居道德之先，故无生无死。 世人在道德之后，故有死有生。 得之者无取，失之者莫寻。 在无德无取之中谓之得道，於有作有用之际谓之得德。 矧乎其有，全不知道德浮泛、生死流浪性命者，不可胜纪，故老子说《道经》焉、《德经》焉。 三十八章 上德不德，是以用也有德； 下德不失德，是以无德。 上德之人，不恃其德，故有其德。 下德之人，常执其德，故无其德。 上德无为而无以为，下德为之而有以为。 上德无为，无事可为。 下德有为，有所作为。 上仁为之而无以为，上义为之而有以为。 上仁合德，亦无可为。 上义制断，以有可为。 上礼为之而莫之应，则攘臂而仍之。 上礼有求，故无以应之。 攘臂者，时谓展手取物也。 礼为执行五常也。 故失道而后德，失德而后仁，失仁而后义，失义而后礼。 夫礼者，忠信之薄而乱之首。 失自然而后有德业，失德业有仁行，失仁行有义路，失义路有礼仪。 存礼仪，则薄於忠信，而失自然，为紊乱之首也。 前识者，道之华而愚之始。 世之愚人，只见其前，不顾其后，只慕其始，不保其终，譬之果木，但爱其华叶，不取其结实也。 是以大丈夫处其厚不处其薄，居其实不居其华， 处其重厚，不居浮薄。 取其结实，不爱华叶。 故去彼取此。 去彼之华，取此之实。 三十九章 昔之得一者，天得一一谓正道以清清静也，地得一以宁安宁也，神得一以灵通灵也，谷得一以盈盈满也，万物得一以生生长也，王侯得一以为天下政政化也。 其致之谓弃一也，天无以清将恐裂毁裂也，地无以宁将恐发发泄也，神无以灵将恐歇虚歇也，谷无以盈将恐竭空竭也，万物无以生将恐灭灭绝也，王侯无以贵高将恐蹙颠蹙也。 故贵以贱为本，高以下为基。 贵因贱显贵，高因下显高。 是以侯王自谓孤寡不毂， 车毂也，谓众辐所凑。 此其以贱为本耶？ 非？

**The Classic of Virtue**

Those who expound the Dao say:
The origin of all things is formless—this is the Dao.
The function of all things is manifest—this is Virtue.

Virtue arises from the Dao,
The Dao is fulfilled through Virtue.
The highest Virtue and the highest Dao are one.

To grasp it is to live;
To lose it is to die.

The Sage abides before Virtue and the Dao,
Thus knows neither birth nor death.

Common folk dwell after Virtue and the Dao,
Thus know birth and death.

To grasp it requires no taking;
To lose it is beyond recovery.

To dwell in the absence of Virtue and taking—this is to attain the Dao.
To act and employ—this is to attain Virtue.

How much more so for those who, amid their very existence,
Fail to grasp the floating, boundless nature of Virtue and the Dao,
And drift through life and death, their vital essence wandering—
These are countless, and thus Laozi spoke of the *Dao Jing* and the *De Jing*.

**Chapter 38**
The highest Virtue does not cling to Virtue,
Yet through this very non-clinging, Virtue is employed.
The lowest Virtue does not lose Virtue,
Yet through this very clinging, Virtue is lost.

The Sage of highest Virtue acts without action,
Yet nothing remains undone.
The Sage of lowest Virtue acts with action,
Yet much is left incomplete.

The highest Benevolence acts without action,
Yet nothing remains undone.
The highest Righteousness acts with action,
Yet much is left incomplete.

The highest Benevolence harmonizes with Virtue,
Yet nothing remains to be done.
The highest Righteousness enforces judgments,
Yet there are things to be enforced.

The highest Rites act, yet none respond,
So they forcefully seize and compel.
The highest Rites demand response,
Yet none comply.

*Seizing by force* refers to what is now called *unfurling the arm to take*—
The Rites are the execution of the Five Constants.
Thus, when the Dao is lost, Virtue arises;
When Virtue is lost, Benevolence arises;
When Benevolence is lost, Righteousness arises;
When Righteousness is lost, the Rites arise.

The Rites are the thinnest layer of loyalty and trust,
Yet they are the beginning of chaos.
When naturalness is lost, Virtue and deeds arise;
When Virtue and deeds are lost, Benevolent actions arise;
When Benevolent actions are lost, the path of Righteousness arises;
When the path of Righteousness is lost, Rites and ceremonies arise.

To uphold Rites and ceremonies is to thin loyalty and trust,
And to lose naturalness—
This is the origin of disorder.

**Foreknowledge** is the flower of the Dao,
Yet it is the beginning of folly.

The foolish of the world see only what is before them,
Not what lies behind;
They covet only the beginning,
Not the end.
It is like a fruit tree—
They love only its blossoms and leaves,
Yet do not take its fruit.

Thus, the true man dwells in substance, not in the thin;
In reality, not in the superficial;
In the weighty, not in the hollow;
In the fruit, not in the flower.

Hence, he discards the latter to take the former—
Discards the flower to take the fruit.

**Chapter 39**
In ancient times, those who attained *Oneness*:
The heavens attained *Oneness* with serene clarity,
The earth attained *Oneness* with tranquil stability,
The spirit attained *Oneness* with luminous responsiveness,
The valleys attained *Oneness* with fullness,
All things attained *Oneness* with flourishing growth,
And kings and lords attained *Oneness* to govern and transform the world.

Yet when *Oneness* is exhausted—
The heavens, without clarity, risk fracturing and ruin,
The earth, without stability, risks erupting and overflowing,
The spirit, without responsiveness, risks fading and vanishing,
The valleys, without fullness, risk draining and emptiness,
All things, without growth, risk perishing and extinction,
And kings and lords, without nobility, risk humiliation and downfall.

Thus, nobility finds its root in humility,
And height finds its foundation in lowliness.
Nobility shines through humility,
Height is revealed through lowliness.

Therefore, lords and kings call themselves *lonely and few*—
*Poor* (孤), like the hub of a wheel,
Where all spokes converge.
Is this not their rooting in humility?
Or is it not?

Thus, when virtue is perfected, there is no praise—
Loneliness and fewness are the true marks.
When lords and kings’ virtue extends to all under heaven,
They count their virtues not to receive praise,
But lest they become polished like jade,
Or rugged like stone.
Jade is scarce and thus noble,
Stone is common and thus lowly—
The virtuous do not seek nobility but seek humility.

**Chapter Forty**
The Way moves by returning,
The weak are the Way’s use.
All things under heaven arise from *Having*,
*Having* arises from *Non-Having*.
Motion and stillness align with the Way,
Softness and weakness embody the Way.
All things are born from *Having*,
Yet return to *Non-Having*.

**Chapter Forty-One**
The superior person hears the Way and strives to practice it;
The mediocre person hears the Way and holds it as if it exists, as if it does not;
The inferior person hears the Way and laughs—
If they do not laugh, it is not the Way.

The superior person is born of pure *qi* and, hearing the Way, strives to practice it;
The mediocre person is born of harmonious *qi* and, hearing the Way, holds it as if it exists, as if it does not;
The inferior person is born of turbid *qi* and knows nothing of the Way.
The Way opposes the common, so it is met with laughter.

There is a saying:
When the Way is first spoken,
Its clarity seems like darkness;
After the Way is made clear,
It seems like perpetual obscurity.
Advancing the Way appears as retreat,
Hiding one’s traces and concealing one’s name
Is how one truly advances the Way.
The Way’s equality is like that of the common,
The great Way is level and just, like ordinary things.
Great virtue seems like the vulgar,
Though virtue resides above, it does not abandon the common.
Great purity seems like shame,
The most virtuous appear as if dishonored.
Great breadth seems insufficient,
Virtue vast as the heavens still seems lacking.
Establishing virtue seems like theft,
Those who build virtue act as if stealing, fearing others’ knowledge.
True substance seems false,
The genuine appears as if corrupted.
The most square has no corners,
The greatest boundaries are boundless.
Great vessels take long to form,
Those who craft the grand cannot rush completion.
The greatest sound is without tone,
The mightiest thunder does not roar endlessly.
The greatest form is shapeless,
The grandest symbol—heaven and earth—has no fixed shape.
The Way is hidden, nameless.
Only the Way
Lends freely and fulfills.

**Chapter Forty-Two**
The Way gives birth to *Oneness*,
*Oneness* gives birth to the Two,
The Two gives birth to the Three,
The Three gives birth to all things.
All things bear *yin* and embrace *yang*,
And through their clashing *qi* find harmony.
What people detest—
Loneliness, fewness, the hub of the wheel—
Is what kings and lords claim as their name.
Thus, some things are diminished to benefit,
And benefited to diminish.
The Way gives birth to *One Qi*,
*One Qi* gives birth to the Two Poles,
The Two Poles give birth to the Three Powers,
The Three Powers give birth to all things.
All things bear *yin* and embrace *yang*,
Using clashing *qi* to harmonize above and below.
Taking loneliness and fewness as the model of kings and lords,
The principle of diminishing and benefiting is the way of all things.
What people teach,
I also teach as my principle.
The overbearing meet no good end.
I shall make them my lesson,
Using the overbearing as a warning
To keep all steadfast in softness and weakness.

**Chapter Forty-Three**
The most gentle under heaven
Overcomes the most rigid under heaven.
Softness overcomes hardness—
There is no entering where there is no gap,
Thus one knows the benefit of *wuwei*.
The teaching of *wuwei* is without words,
Its benefit is without action—
Few under heaven attain it.
*Wuwei* enters where there is no gap,
The benefit of *wuwei* is without action—
Few under heaven attain it.
*Xi* means few.

**Chapter Forty-Five**
What is more cherished—name or body?
What is more abundant—body or wealth?
What brings greater suffering—gain or loss?
Thus, the more one loves excessively, the greater the expenditure;
The more one hoards, the greater the loss.
Therefore, one who knows sufficiency is unshamed,
One who knows restraint is unharmed,
And thus may endure long.

Name is distant, the body is close—
Do not harm the body to pursue name.
The body is few, wealth is much—
Do not forfeit the body to seek wealth.
Gain brings its own suffering, loss brings its own suffering;
Love brings expenditure, hoarding brings loss.
To endure long, know sufficiency and guard your portion—
Then you shall not face peril.

**Chapter Forty-Six**
The fully formed seems incomplete—
Its use is never exhausted.
The utterly full seems empty—
Its use is never depleted.
The perfectly straight seems bent,
The supremely skillful seems clumsy,
The eloquent seem tongue-tied.
Agitation overcomes cold,
Stillness overcomes heat,
And clarity-quietude governs the world.

When virtue and power are complete,
To be called deficient and yielding is proper—
Thus its use is never exhausted or depleted,
So the straight seems bent,
Skill seems clumsiness,
Eloquence seems speechlessness.
Agitation and heat are names for disturbance,
Cold and stillness are the realm of non-action—
The foundation of true principle.

**Chapter Forty-Seven**
When the Way prevails in the world,
Warhorses are used for plowing fields.
When the Way does not prevail,
Warhorses and arms arise in the suburbs.
A ruler who follows the Way
Does not use warhorses but tends the fields.
When the Way is lost,
Warhorses fill the countryside—
This is the love of arms.
To tend the fields is to encourage agriculture;
To love arms is to harm the people.
No guilt is greater than desiring what is forbidden,
No calamity is greater than not knowing sufficiency,
No blame is worse than greed.
Thus, sufficiency’s sufficiency is always sufficient.
The guilt of desire is the pursuit of one’s will—
Disaster and blame fall upon oneself.
If one does not know sufficiency,
It is the love of greed.
Thus, knowing sufficiency,
All things are sufficient.

**Chapter Forty-Eight**
Not stepping outside, one knows the world;
Not peering through windows, one sees the Way.
The farther one goes, the less one knows.
Thus the Sage acts without going yet knows,
Sees without looking yet is named,
Accomplishes without doing.
The Way of the world is one—
The household and the world differ not.
Only cultivate the inner,
And the outer is known.
The Way of Heaven and the Way of Man unite—
Only cultivate the self,
And the Way of Heaven must respond.
What need is there for distant travel or peering through windows?
Thus the Sage does not seek outside,
Does not take from what is seen or heard,
Does not gain through speech or debate—
Spontaneously, all is accomplished.

**Chapter Forty-Nine**
For learning, daily increase;
For the Way, daily diminish.
Diminish again, diminish again,
Until reaching *wuwei*.
When there is *wuwei*, nothing is left undone.
To take the world with non-action,
Yet when action arises, it is insufficient to take the world.
To study extensively brings daily gain.
To cultivate virtue and power brings daily loss—
Meaning to diminish desires.
Until reaching the state of *wuwei* and non-action,
Then the hearts of the world are easily taken.

**Chapter Fifty**
The Sage has no fixed heart,
Taking the hearts of the people as heart.
The people have desires, the Sage acts with *wuwei*.
With a heart of *wuwei*, following the hearts of desire,
This is in accordance with nature.
The good, I treat well;
The unkind, I also treat well—thus I gain goodness.
The trustworthy, I trust;
The untrustworthy, I also trust—thus I gain trust.
The good, though good, I treat well—
The unkind, though unkind, I treat well—
Thus I attain the Way of goodness.
The trustworthy, I trust;
The untrustworthy, I also trust—
Thus I attain the principle of trust.

The Sage in the world is weary and diligent,
Blending his heart with the people’s.
The people all fix their ears and eyes upon him,
The Sage takes pity on them all.
The Sage, weary and diligent,
Merges his heart with the people’s—
The people gaze and await his favor,
The Sage takes pity on them all.

**Chapter Fifty-One**
Born, entering death,

「Cultivating the Dao brings forth life; indulging in desires leads to death.
Of those who seek life, there are thirteen types;
Of those who court death, there are thirteen types;
And among those who move between life and death, there are thirteen kinds of people.
Why is this so?
Because the pursuit of life is profound and thick.
In this world, birth and death are constants.
Even if death is three parts out of ten, there remains a path to life.
Even if life is three parts out of ten, it is still a path to death.
For though the desire for life is great, one cannot escape death and birth,
Thus, movement brings one into perilous deathly terrain.

It is heard that those who practice good *shèyǎng* (nurturing and cultivation) avoid death:
On land, they do not meet *xì* (rhinoceros) or *hǔ* (tigers),
In battle, they are not struck by armor or weaponry.
For those who harm others, the *xì* has horns, the *hǔ* has claws, and weapons have blades.
But if the *xì* finds no place to lodge its horn,
The *hǔ* finds no place to strike with its claw,
And weapons find no place to fit their blades—
Why is this so?
Because there is no deathly terrain.
On land, they know dawn and dusk;
In battle, they recognize advance and retreat.
Skilled in self-nurturance, adept at avoiding harm,
Thus, they have no deathly terrain.

**Chapter Fifty-Two**
The Dao is the origin of all things under heaven; it is the Mother of the world.
Having obtained its Mother, one knows its children—all things.
Having known its children, one must again guard its Mother, guard the Dao,
And thus, throughout life, one will not perish.
All things arise from the Dao, so it is their Mother.
The Mother must be known to understand its children,
The children must be known to understand the Mother.
Guarding the Mother and children in harmony,
One does not lose the Dao, and thus the body remains unharmed.
Seal its senses—close its eyes and ears—
And shut its gates and doors—
One will never labor throughout life.
Open its gates, aid its affairs,
And one will never be saved.
Those who guard the Dao do not prize speech or debate,
Nor do they gaze upon beauty or vice.
Those who defy it will find no end to their misfortunes,
Nor will their bodies escape toil and weariness.

Seeing the small as *míng* (clear/bright),
*Míng* perceives its subtleties.
Guarding softness as *qiáng* (strong),
Using its radiance—
The Dao returns to its *míng*,
Leaving no bodily calamity—
This is called *xié cháng* (following constancy).
For all things, from small to great,
Guarding softness as strength,
Action returns to the Dao,
Never losing its constancy—
Thus, there is no bodily harm.

**Chapter Fifty-Three**
If I were to be *jiè shàn* (distinctly virtuous) and yet have knowledge,
Walking the Great Dao,
I would fear only *shī* (giving/imposing).
If I were to know well,
There would be the Great Dao.
What I fear is that giving and imposing cannot be done as the common people would,
For knowing the Dao is easy, but walking it is difficult.

The Great Dao is most level,
Yet people prefer shortcuts.
The Great Dao is like a plain road,
But people do not like to walk it;
They all go down the crooked paths.

Morning is most *chú* (clear/empty),
Yet daily it is obscured by change—
Changing clothes, altering utensils and vessels,
Delighting in slaves, carriages, houses, and dwellings,
The fields are full of sprouts, yet the granaries remain empty—
The fields though planted, the granaries though full of crops, are still void,
Speaking of extravagant expenditure.
Clothing in fine colors and textures—
Wearing silk, brocade, cotton, and embroidered garments—
And adorning oneself with sharp blades—
Taking pleasure in bows and swords.

「To loathe food and drink,
One has no time to cook and butcher.

Wealth and goods are in excess,
Amassing treasures and riches—
Hoarding gold and jade.

This is called *dào kuà* (plundering/usurpation),
Is it not contrary to the Dao?

What one takes delight in thus,
Differs not from thieves and bandits.
Those who plunder are not virtuous.

**Chapter 54:**
*Good at establishing cannot be uprooted,*
Good at establishing matters—
They cannot be torn away.

*Good at embracing does not loosen,*
Good at embracing the Dao—
They cannot be shaken or abandoned.

Descendants sacrifice at the ancestral mounds without ceasing.
Those with virtue—
Their descendants, generation after generation, never cease in sacrifice.

Practice it upon oneself,
And its power becomes true;
True and unerring.

Practice it within the family,
And its power overflows;
Virtue and deeds abound.

Practice it in the village,
And its power endures;
Its influence is long-lasting.

Practice it in the state,
And its power flourishes—
All things prosper.

Practice it throughout the world,
And its power becomes universal.
Its virtue and blessings are far-reaching.

Therefore, observe oneself with the Dao,
To cultivate oneself brings fortune,
To neglect it brings misfortune.

Observe the family with the Dao,
To cultivate the family brings harmony,
To neglect it brings chaos.

Observe the village with the Dao,
To cultivate the village brings peace,
To neglect it brings strife.

Observe the state with the Dao.
To cultivate the state brings good governance,
To neglect it brings ruin.

Observe the world with the Dao.
To cultivate the world brings unity,
To neglect it brings fragmentation.

How do I know the world is thus?
By this—
The sage uses this Dao,
To observe the world.

**Chapter 55:**
*Discarding virtue’s depth,*
Comparable to an infant.

Poisonous insects do not sting,
Fierce birds and wild beasts do not attack.
*Plunderers* do not harm.

Deeply yielding, containing virtue—
Always like an infant,
With no scheming toward things,
Thus birds and beasts see them and do not harm.

*Attack* is akin to harm.

Bones weak, sinews soft yet grip firm—
An infant is soft and weak,
Though soft and weak, yet able to hold fast and solid,
For *primordial qi* is present.

Not knowing the union of *playing yin* (dark/soft principle),
Yet *jùn* (complete) in essence—
*Qi* is refined and solidified.

Crying all day yet voice does not scatter—
The utmost harmony.

*Playing yin*, the Dao of husband and wife.
What they do not yet know,
Then *zhēng* (pure) essence remains constant.
Crying yet not scattering—
Speaking of harmony in *qi* being achieved.

Knowing harmony is called *constancy*,
Nurturing life is called *deliberation*—
Carefully measuring essence and *qi*.
The heart directs *qi*—
Called *strengthening*.

Not directing it, it abides.
Things grow strong, then age—
Called *not the Dao*.
Not the Dao comes early.

Able to know harmony in *qi* always present,
Use the heart to deliberate carefully,
To make resources benefit the body as *strengthening* and clarity,
And long preserve softness and weakness—
Strongness is *not the Dao*.

**Chapter 56:**
*The wise do not speak,*
Those who speak are not wise.»

**Chapter 57:**
Seal its openings,
Close its gates,
Dull its sharpness,
Release its anger,
Blend its radiance,
Merge with the dust—
This is called *mysterious unity*.

Thus, it cannot be made close,
Cannot be made distant,
Cannot be made beneficial,
Cannot be made harmful,
Cannot be made noble,
Cannot be made lowly—
Therefore, it is held in highest esteem by the world.

The wise do not speak,
For they guard the Dao.
The unwise speak constantly,
Yet seek to enact their Dao.

The wise seal openings and close gates,
Dull sharpness and release anger,
Blend radiance and merge with dust—
Thus, they have no close or distant,
No benefit or harm,
No nobility or lowliness,
And align with the Dao in *mysterious virtue*,
Therefore attaining the world’s highest esteem.
The unwise do the opposite.

**Chapter 58:**
Govern the realm with *non-action*,
Conquer with *unexpectedness*,
Take the world with *inaction*.

How do I know the world is thus?
From this:
*Non-action* can govern the realm,
*Unexpectedness* can wage war.

In waging war, the general employs strange strategies,
Drives the enemy to death’s ground—
Do not show them pity or sincerity.
In governing the realm, to bring peace to the people,
Do not display cunning or deceit.
First remove your own calamities,
Then you may expand territory and open borders.

The Sage knows these two principles,
Thus governing is as it is.

The world abounds in taboos,
Yet people grow ever poorer;
Taboos multiply, rebellions arise—
Thus, laws are established.
Taboos do not follow desire,
Thus punishments are enforced.

People wield many sharp tools,
And the state grows ever more confused;
People use benefit and harm as tools—
This is the confusion of governance.

People abound in cleverness,
And strange things proliferate;
When cleverness and novelty flourish,
Strange things arise to deceive the masses.
Laws proliferate, yet thieves and robbers multiply.
Thieves and robbers rise in number,
Because they fear the laws and act accordingly.

Thus the Sage says:
I act with *non-action*, yet people transform themselves.
I impose no order, yet all is accomplished.
I take no action, yet people prosper—
Each follows their own desires.
I love stillness, yet people govern themselves—
No laws are set to oversee them.
I desire nothing, yet people return to simplicity.
No artificial teachings are established,
Yet none dare to presume knowledge.

chunks.original_text: 其政闷闷，其人蠢蠢； 其政察察，其人缺缺。 为政闷闷，其人蠢静。 为政孜切，其人残缺。 祸，福之所倚侍也； 福，祸之所伏藏也。 孰谁也知其极？ 人倚有祸，修福助之。 不知福生，却有祸至。 其无政。 失其治也。 政为奇，善复为谈。 人之迷，其日固久。 是以圣人方而不割，廉而不秽，直而不肆，光而不耀。 失其政洽，政事翻作奇诈，善事复为訞乱，人迷惑久固於斯。 圣人方圆而不割，廉慎而不秽浊，正直而不申肆，韬光而不晶耀也。 五十九章 治人事天，莫若式法也。 夫唯式，是以早伏。 早伏谓之重积德，重积德则无不充，无不充，莫知其极。 能知其极，可以有国。 有国之母母犹道也，可以久长。 深根固蒂深植其根，蒂无标落。 长生久视之道。 治人情，事天时，莫若守法式，故得万物早归伏。 归伏之后为重积德，积德充满，莫知物之穷极。 能知穷极，可以治国，然后为母。 深根固蒂，为善保国家，可大可久也。 六十章 治大国，若烹小腥小腥杂类。 以道莅临也天下，其鬼不神。 非其鬼不神，其神不伤人，非其神不伤人，圣人亦不伤人。 夫两不相伤，故德交归。 圣人在上，禽鱼遂性，而况於国乎？ 以道莅天下者，时气雍和，淫厉不作，故鬼不能为神也。 万物皆有其神，为神则伤人。 唯正神不伤人，圣人体道，亦不伤人，故交归於德。 六十一章 大国者下流，天下之郊，天下之郊牝。 牝，雌也，为柔。 常以静雌守静也胜牡。 牡，雄也，为刚。 大国如川源下流，众物皆归，天下混一，四方为郊，常以柔胜刚也。 故大国以下小国，则取小国； 小国以下大国，则聚大国。 故或下而取，或下而聚。 夫大国不过欲兼畜人，小国不过欲入事人。 夫两者各得其所欲，大欲畜，小欲事。 故大者宜为下。 大国以礼小国，小国以礼大国，大国欲畜人，小国入事人。 虽两有所求，大者宜下取。 六十二章 道者万物之奥，善人之宝，不善人之所不保。 深奥者莫过於道，善人所为你宝，不善人不解所保持。 美言可以市，尊行可以加人。 善能取与。 人之不善，奚弃之有？ 故立天子，置三公， 天子治三公，三公治百职，百职治万民，故无弃人。 虽有拱璧以四马骏马，不如坐进此道。 道与四马拱璧皆能行，唯修道者身不往。 古之所以贵此道者，何不曰求以得，有罪以免？ 故为天下贵。 古者云：不须日行大道，济利一切，但无罪僭，便为贵也。 六十三章 为无为无作用也，事无事不劳役也，味无味守淡泊也。 大小多少，报怨以德。 大之与小，多之与少，尽以德服之，必无怨恶也。 图难於易，为大於细微也。 天下难事，必作於易，大事必作於小。 凡事先易后难，从小至大，则难事易为，大事易作。 夫轻诺必寡信， 先轻唯诺，后必无应。 多易必多难。 容易施为，终难成立。 是以圣人犹难之，故终无难。 历试诸难，后成功德。 六十四章 其安易持， 安静则易保持。 其未兆易谋， 未有形兆，则易谋度。 其毳易破， 当织毳时，则易破除。 其微易散。 物微小，则易为分散。 为之於未有，治之於未乱。 治乱於未乱之前，为事於未成之际，豫备不虞。 合抱之木，生於毫末； 九重之台，起於累土； 百仞之高，起於足下。 从微至着，以小成大。 为者败之，执者失之。

The governance grows sluggish, and the people grow dull;
The governance becomes meticulous, and the people grow deficient.

When governance is sluggish, the people grow quiet and docile.
When governance is overzealous, the people grow mutilated and incomplete.

Calamity and fortune dwell as companions;
Fortune hides within calamity.
Who can truly know their limits?
People lean toward calamity, yet cultivate virtue to aid them.
Unknowing of fortune’s birth, they invite calamity instead.
Thus, when there is no governance,
The people lose their order.

When governance becomes contrived, virtue turns to idle talk.
The people’s confusion grows ever deeper.
Therefore, the Sage is square yet does not cut,
Sharp yet does not soil,
Straight yet does not overreach,
Bright yet does not dazzle.
When governance fails to harmonize,
Governance becomes deceitful trickery,
Virtue becomes chaotic confusion,
And the people’s bewilderment endures.
The Sage is square and round yet does not cut,
Prudent yet not impure,
Upright yet not aggressive,
Concealing brightness yet not blinding.

---

To govern people and serve Heaven,
Nothing surpasses adhering to the *Dao*.
Only by adhering does one lie low early.
To lie low early is to accumulate virtue deeply,
To accumulate virtue deeply is to be ever full,
To be ever full is to know no bounds.
To know the bounds is to govern a realm.
The mother of governing a realm is the *Dao*,
And it endures eternally.
Deep roots and firm foundations—
Plant its roots deep, lest they be uprooted.
The *Dao* of enduring life and long vision.

To govern human nature and follow Heaven’s timing,
Nothing surpasses adhering to laws and patterns,
Thus all things submit early.
After submission comes deep virtue accumulation,
Virtue accumulation fills all things,
No one knows their limits.
To know the limits is to govern a realm,
Then to become its mother.
Deep roots and firm foundations—
To preserve the state, vast and enduring.

---

To govern a great realm,
Treat it as you would a delicate dish—
A delicate dish requires careful handling.
When the *Dao* is applied to govern the world,
Its spirits are not feared.
Not that its spirits are not feared,
But that they do not harm people—
Not that they do not harm people,
But that the Sage does not harm people.
When neither harms the other,
Virtue returns in exchange.
The Sage above, and beasts and fish follow their nature—
How much more so the people?
When the *Dao* governs the world,
The seasons harmonize, and excess or harshness do not arise,
Thus the spirits cannot become malevolent.
All things have their spirits,
And when they become spirits, they harm people.
Only the true spirit does not harm,
The Sage embodies the *Dao* and does not harm,
Thus virtue returns in exchange.

---

Great realms are the confluence of the world,
The outskirts of the world,
The world’s outskirts are receptive—
Receptive, like the female.
The female is yielding, and yielding overcomes the male.
The male is strong, and strong is overcome by yielding.
Great realms, like rivers flowing downward,
All things gather there.
The world unifies, and the four quarters become its outskirts,
Ever victorious through yielding.
Thus, great realms submit to small realms and take them,
Small realms submit to great realms and gather under them.
Thus, some submit to take, others submit to gather.
Great realms desire only to nurture people,
Small realms desire only to serve them.
Both obtain what they desire—
Great realms desire to nurture, small realms desire to serve.
Thus, the great should submit.

Great realms treat small realms with propriety,
Small realms treat great realms with propriety.
Great realms desire to nurture people,
Small realms desire to serve them.
Though both have desires, the great should submit to take.

---

The *Dao* is the hidden essence of all things,
The treasure of the virtuous,
The refuge of the unvirtuous.
Its depth is unmatched.
The virtuous cherish it as their treasure,
The unvirtuous cannot preserve it.
Fine words can be sold,
Noble conduct can elevate one.
The skillful give and take.
Why abandon those who are unvirtuous?
Thus, the Son of Heaven is established,
And the Three Ministers are appointed.
The Son of Heaven governs the Three Ministers,
The Three Ministers govern the myriad offices,
The myriad offices govern the people—
Thus, no one is abandoned.
Though one may possess a jade tablet and four swift horses,
It is not as precious as yielding to this *Dao*.
The *Dao* and the four swift horses with jade tablet can both be used,
Yet only those who cultivate the *Dao* do not need to go themselves.
Anciently, why was this *Dao* so honored?
Was it not for seeking to obtain and avoiding guilt?
Thus, it is prized by the world.
The ancients said:
*"Do not needlessly walk the great *Dao*,
Yet benefit all—
Only avoid guilt and presumption,
And that is true nobility."*

---

To act without action is to act without contrivance,
To govern without governance is to labor without toil,
To savor without taste is to embrace simplicity.
Great and small, many and few—
Repay resentment with virtue.
The great and the small, the many and the few—
All are served by virtue, and none will harbor grudges.
Difficult things begin with ease,
Great things arise from the minute.
The world’s difficult tasks must begin with ease,
Great deeds must arise from the small.
Light promises bring few fulfillments,
Easy words lead to later failure.
Much ease brings much difficulty.
What seems simple in execution often fails in completion.
Thus, the Sage treats difficulty as difficulty,
And so never faces true difficulty.
Testing through all difficulties,
Then achieving success through virtue.

---

What is settled is easy to preserve.
What is not yet manifest is easy to plan.
What is woven is easy to unravel.
What is minute is easy to disperse.
Act before it exists,
Govern before it is disordered.
To govern disorder before it arises,
To act before it is complete—
To prepare for the unforeseen.
A tree thick as an embrace begins as a shoot;
A nine-tiered tower rises from a clod of earth;
A height of a hundred *ren* begins at one’s feet.
From the minute to the manifest,
From the small to the great.
Those who act destroy it,
Those who grasp lose it.

The Sage acts without action, hence no failure.
The Sage does not grasp, hence no loss.
Humans, in their undertakings, often succeed at the subtle and fail at the manifest.
To treat the end as carefully as the beginning—then there will be no failed undertakings.
The common people, clinging to desires, act and thus stray.
The Sage acts without action, seeing neither decline nor flourishing.
The common people cannot reverence the beginning nor carefully treat the end; as soon as they plan to act, they are already doomed to failure.
Thus, the Sage desires without desiring,
Does not prize difficult-to-obtain wealth;
Learns without learning,
Prepares for the faults of others,
And aids the natural unfolding of all things without daring to act.
To desire when one should not desire,
To learn when one should not learn,
To not value wealth and possessions,
To not covet fame and rank—
Thus, one prepares for the faults of others,
And aids the completion of all things,
Bringing them to their natural state—
This is the essence of the Sage.

**Chapter 65**
The ancients who were skilled in the Dao did not enlighten people,
But sought to delight and bring them joy.
The difficulty of governing people lies in their knowing,
For knowing creates distinctions.
To govern with wisdom is ruin for the state;
To govern without wisdom is to enrich the state’s virtue.
Knowing these two—governing with wisdom and without—
Is the standard and fixed law.
To always know the standard is called the profound virtue of governing the profound.
Deep and far-reaching virtue,
Opposing the ways of things,
Only then reaches the great harmony.
The ancients who governed did not force people to distinguish good and evil,
But only wished to make them joyful, without knowledge or awareness.
If they had knowledge, they would be difficult to govern.
Wisdom breeds deceit; deep cunning is a thief, the source of harm.
The profound virtue employs the standard,
Exhausting all circumstances,
Returning to great harmony.

**Chapter 66**
The reason the rivers and seas can be kings of all valleys
Is that they excel in humility,
Thus they become kings of all valleys.
Rivers and seas flow downward,
And all valleys return to them.
Thus, the Sage wishes to be above others by speaking humbly;
This is called compassionate concern.
The Sage wishes to lead others by placing himself last;
This is called aiding and guiding.
Thus, when in a high position, he does not burden others with heavy demands;
When in the forefront, he does not harm others.
Therefore, all under heaven willingly follow without exhaustion.
Because he does not contend,
None under heaven can contend with him.
The Sage in office has a mind to serve below and honor above,
In the forefront has the virtue of placing others first and himself last—
None grow weary of him,
And all willingly follow daily—
Who could contend with him?

**Chapter 67**
All under heaven consider me great, yet I do not laugh.
Only because I am great do I seem not to laugh.
If I laughed for long, I would be small.
The Dao is the greatest under heaven,
Thus it cannot be laughed at or compared.
Because it is great, it is not laughed at or compared.
If one laughs at or compares it for long,
Then it is indeed small.
I have three treasures, which I hold fast:
The first is compassion,
The second is frugality,
The third is not daring to be first under heaven.
With compassion, frugality, and not being first as my three treasures,
The Sage holds them as precious.
Compassion makes one courageous—
Compassion saves all things, hence courage arises.
Frugality makes one abundant—
Frugality moderates use, hence abundance arises.
Not daring to be first makes one a vessel and leader—
Not being first is humility, hence one attains leadership.
Now, to abandon compassion and courage,
To abandon frugality and abundance,
To abandon placing others last and oneself first—
This is the path to death.
Now, to be courageous without compassion,
Abundant without frugality,
First without placing others last—
This is the path to death.
Compassion, when arraying troops, brings order;
When defending, it secures cities.
Heaven, about to save them, guards with compassion.
Troops arrayed with compassion do not kill;
Cities defended with compassion are not harmed.
In accordance with Heaven and the people,
There is natural salvation and protection.

**Chapter 68**
The ancients skilled in being a scholar did not rely on martial strength,
But established the Way of governance.
Skilled warriors do not rage nor glorify slaughter.
Skilled in defeating enemies, they do not contend;
Their formations are without battle.
Skilled in using people, they place themselves below.
When two armies meet, ritual stands between them.
This is called the virtue of non-contention,
This is called the strength of using people,
This is called aligning with Heaven—
The ancient ultimate.
Martial strength is used to settle difficulties;
Skilled rulers have no difficulties,
Thus they do not glorify martial strength.
If matters cannot be resolved by oneself and arms are used,
One does not rage at the enemy,
Does not contend with the foe,
But submits with ritual,
Seeking victory without aggression—
This is the ancient ultimate law.

**Chapter 69**
There are words about using arms.
The ancients said:
I do not dare to seek to be the aggressor, the first to bring calamity,
But to be the responder.
I do not dare to advance an inch but retreat a foot.
I have no intent to seize.
This is called having no course of action,
Yet having orders.
To sweep away without arms,
Yet having what is to be gathered.
To grasp without weapons,
Yet having weapons without using them.
To have no enemy.
By law, how can there be an enemy?
The greatest calamity is to insult the enemy—
This is lightness in facing the enemy.
To insult the enemy risks losing one’s treasure—
One’s own troops.
Thus, when opposing forces clash,
The compassionate prevail over the cruel.
Though skilled in war and facing no equal,
If one is lighthearted toward the enemy, one will lose oneself.
When two armies clash,
The yielding overcomes the strong.

**Chapter 70**
My words are very easy to know,
Very easy to practice.
Without selfishness, there is no difficulty.
Yet none under heaven can know or practice them—
They are profound and subtle.
Words have their origin,
Affairs have their master.
Speaking follows the origin,
Acting follows the master.
Only because of their lack of knowing,
None know me.
The world has what it does not know,
And the Sage cannot know it either.
Few know me,
Thus I am precious.
Few know the Dao,
Thus the Dao is precious.
Therefore, the Sage wears coarse cloth while cherishing the Dao.

They do not fall ill.

Move with caution in all undertakings,

Do not restrict your dwelling,

Do not exhaust what you are given.

Loves himself but does not exalt himself.
He does not seek fame or recognition—

Brave but daring leads to death,

Bound by Heaven’s Dao/Way—

**Chapter 75**
People do not commonly fear death—
Why then use death to frighten them?
Few in the world escape harm unscathed.
Many indulge in greed and excess,
Unafraid of law and punishment—
This is because they do not fear death.

If people did not fear death,
And yet were to act strangely,
I would test them and kill them.
If people do not fear death,
And yet the world has those who act strangely—
How could I kill them in turn?
Who would dare?

Who would dare kill one who knows death?
Those who execute kill.
Those who wield the law—
To act as the executioner’s substitute
Is to act as the master carpenter’s axe.
Those who wield the law wield power.
To act as the master carpenter’s axe,
Few escape unharmed.
Even the master carpenter sometimes injures his hand—
Sometimes lightly, sometimes gravely.

---

**Chapter 76**
People starve because their rulers tax them heavily.
Heavy taxation is the cause.
People are hard to govern because their rulers act excessively.
Harsh laws oppress them.
People grow indifferent to death because life is made too luxurious.
They indulge in tastes and hoard jewels and gold.
Only those who do not cling to life are truly noble in valuing it.
Those who seek life excessively perish.
Those who seek life sparingly live.

---

**Chapter 77**
When alive, humans are soft and weak;
When dead, they are stiff and strong.
While spirit and soul remain, they are soft and weak;
When scattered, they become stiff and strong.
All things—grasses and trees—
While living, are soft and yielding.
While dying, they wither and decay.
Qi preserved, they are soft and weak;
Qi exhausted, they wither and decay.
Thus, the stiff and strong belong to death,
The soft and weak belong to life.
Therefore, strong armies do not conquer,
Strong trees split.
Armies must harmonize with the people,
Trees must be of moderate strength.
Thus, the strong and mighty are beneath,
The soft and weak are above.
Branches and twigs are above,
Roots and trunks are below.
Soldiers are in the front,
Commanders are behind.

---

**Chapter 78**
The Dao/Way of Heaven is like drawing a bow:
The high are lowered, the low are raised,
The excessive are diminished, the deficient are supplemented.
The Dao/Way of Heaven diminishes the excessive and supplements the deficient.
But human affairs are not so:
They diminish the deficient to serve the excessive.
Heaven values harmony and compliance,
A bow values balance and uniformity—
No bias toward large or small,
No disparity between high and low.
By this, the world is governed—
This is called *Great Peace*.
Human affairs are not so:
They honor the strong and suppress the weak,
Favor the few and serve the many—
This is called *seizing power*.
Who can serve the world with what they have in excess?
Only the Daoist.

Divide what is above to aid what is lacking.
Thus, the Sage acts without claiming credit,
Achieves without dwelling on success—
This is why they are not esteemed.
The Sage pushes merit forward and declines rewards,
Extending virtue to the worthy and the good.

---

**Chapter 79**
Nothing in the world is as soft and weak as water,
Yet nothing surpasses it in attacking the firm and strong.
It cannot be replaced.
Water can temper steel—
It cannot be altered.
Thus, the soft overcomes the hard,
The weak overcomes the strong.
Few in the world know this,
Fewer still can practice it.
Yin consumes Yang,
The soft overcomes the strong—
Few in the world know this,
Fewer still can practice it.

To bear a nation’s impurities—
This is called the *Lord of the Soil*.
To bear a nation’s misfortunes—
This is called the *King of the World*.
Straight speech seems contrary.
When a nation faces hardship, the feudal lords bear it.
When the world faces calamity, only the King governs it.
This is called the *Dao/Way of governance*.

Forcing them to risk death and flee to distant lands.
The Sage, wishing to enact the great Dao/Way,
Does not rely on talent and cunning,
But makes others hold death in reverence and not go.
Depart (徙) is to move (移).
Though there are boats and carriages,
There is no place to embark;
No labor of movement.
Though there are arms and armor,
There is no place to array them;
No warfare.
They return to using knotted cords (结绳),
Reverting to simplicity (还淳).
Sweet their food, fine their clothing—
No hunger, no cold.
Secure their dwellings, content their customs—
Families well-provided, people at ease,
No levies or forced labor.
Neighboring states are visible to one another,
Four borders unassailed.
Cock’s crow and dog’s bark are heard between them,
Neighbors dwell in close proximity.»

Ornate words are not true.

Those who amass knowledge are not wise.
No need for inquiry.

Those who argue are not virtuous.
No need for embellishment.

Others serve the Sage—
